## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 388, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 1 (S1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 322, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 495, 505, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 598, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 608, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 757, 676]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 676, 440, 691]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The time taken, in minutes, by a ferry to cross a lake has a normal distribution with mean 85 and standard deviation 6.8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, on a randomly chosen occasion, the time taken by the ferry to cross the lake is between 79 and 91 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 186, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 504, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
Over a long period it is found that \(96\%\) of ferry crossings take longer than a certain time \(t\) minutes. Find the value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 544]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Megan sends messages to her friends in one of 3 different ways: text, email or social media. For each message, the probability that she uses text is 0.3 and the probability that she uses email is 0.2. She receives an immediate reply from a text message with probability 0.4, from an email with probability 0.15 and from social media with probability 0.6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 150, 156, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 149, 670, 168]]<|/det|>
Draw a fully labelled tree diagram to represent this information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 562, 153, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 562, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
Given that Megan does not receive an immediate reply to a message, find the probability that the message was an email.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 580, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 165, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways a committee of 6 people can be chosen from 8 men and 4 women if there must be at least twice as many men as there are women on the committee. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 191, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways a committee of 6 people can be chosen from 8 men and 4 women if 2 particular men refuse to be on the committee together. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 677, 92]]<|/det|>
On average, \(34\%\) of the people who go to a particular theatre are men.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 14 people who go to the theatre is chosen. Find the probability that at most 2 people are men.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Use an approximation to find the probability that, in a random sample of 600 people who go to the theatre, fewer than 190 are men.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A fair five-sided spinner has sides numbered 1, 1, 1, 2, 3. A fair three-sided spinner has sides numbered 1, 2, 3. Both spinners are spun once and the score is the product of the numbers on the sides the spinners land on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 599, 154]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for the score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 514, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and the variance of the score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 610, 191, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 609, 675, 628]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the score is greater than the mean score.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 609, 920, 628]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The times in minutes taken by 13 pupils at each of two schools in a cross-country race are recorded in the table below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 114, 885, 161]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 734, 92]]<|/det|>
The times taken by pupils at Whitefay Park School are denoted by \(x\) minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 153, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 390, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\Sigma (x - 60)^2\).

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\Sigma (x - 60) = 46\). Use this result, together with your answer to part (iii), to find the variance of \(x\).
